titleStmt.title: A dialogue or accidental discourse betwixt Mr. Alderman Abell, and Richard Kilvert, the two maine projectors for wine, and also Aldermans Abels wife, &c. Contayning their first manner of their acquaintance, how they began to contrive the patent it selfe, how they obtayned it, and who drew the patent. Also in what state they now stand in, and how they accuse and raile at each other with invective speeches, &c. With the manner and fashion how projectors and patentees have rod a tilting in a Parliament time, &c.

titleStmt.title: A dialogue or accidental discourse betwixt Mr. Alderman Abell, and Richard Kilvert, the two maine projectors for wine, and also Aldermans Abels wife, &c. Contayning their first manner of their acquaintance, how they began to contrive the patent it selfe, how they obtayned it, and who drew the patent. Also in what state they now stand in, and how they accuse and raile at each other with invective speeches, &c. With the manner and fashion how projectors and patentees have rod a tilting in a Parliament time, &c.
titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.

publicationStmt.date: Printed also in the same yeare of grace. 1641.

notesStmt.note: Wood cut illustrations on t.p. and p. 8.
Attributed to Thomas Heywood in Wrenn catalogue.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Dialogue or accidental di≈øcour≈øe Betwixt Mr. Alderman Abell, and Richard Kilvert, the two maine Projectors for Wine, and al≈øo Aldermans Abels wife, &c.
Contayning their fir≈øt manner of their acquaintance, how they began to contrive the Patent it ≈øelfe, how they obtayned it, and who drew the patent.

p.hi: Al≈øo in what ≈øtate they now ≈øtand in, and how they accu≈øe and raile at each other with invective ≈øpeeches, &c.

div.p: With the manner and fa≈øhion how Projectors and Patentees have rod a Tilting in a Parlament time, &c.

figure.head: A Pattent for Wine
figure.figDesc: two men, one holding a scroll

div.p: Printed al≈øo in the ≈øame yeare of grace. 1641.

div.head: A Dialogue or accidentall di≈øcour≈øe betwixt Mr. Alderman Abel, and Mr. Richard Kilvert, two maine Projectors, &c.

sp.speaker: Kilvert.
sp.p: MA≈øter Alderman Abell, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: And you Mr Richard K ‚Ä¢ lvert, or I much mi≈øtake my ≈øelfe; good morrow.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: The like to you: and I hope we may live to ≈ø√©e many good dayes hereafter, and though neyther of us have need much to complaine of the Time that's pa≈øt; yet who knowes but the future may prove better then the former, and that's a thing which I thinke both you and I, in our owne particulars, mo≈øt ayme at. O ma≈øter Alderman, I have bin a great gue≈øt to your hou≈øe, I remember you kept then the Ship Taverne behind old Fi≈øh ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Abel
sp.p: I did indeed, hone≈øt Mr. Kilvert, and I thanke God I got a good e≈øtate there by retailing of wine, and by chance in digging a vault neere my ≈øeller, I found ≈øome what which the world ≈øhall never know of, if I had not found ≈øome hidden Trea≈øure in that Cardinals ≈øeller, I had never come to weare this gold chaine, with my thumbs under my girdle: and why are men ≈øparing in their youth, but to get an e≈øtate there by to ≈øpend the more freely in their age? But I pray Ma≈øter Kilvert, what cour≈øe doe you now take? or what Calling do you profe≈ø≈øe or u≈øe?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Who I ma≈øter Alderman, I do u≈øe no Calling, for mony comes into me without Calling or eyther bauling for: I tell you I ≈øtudy the ≈øeavenliberall Arts, and am well ver≈øt in them all, but e≈øpecially in Logicke and Arethmetick, I have them ad unguem, I will tell you, I will never be a≈øhamed of it, I have now got ≈øo much craft, that I excell in cunning. The Theory and Practicke are both mine owne, nay I am ≈øo well in≈øtructed in both, that I dare profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe a Teacher in eyther.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Why, were you ever of any Vniver≈øity?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p:
What tell you me of an Vniver≈øity? There are company of poore Schollers, and ≈øuffer Ballads to be made of them, alas,
the height of their ambition is to be become ≈øome Schole-ma≈øter, or el≈øe ≈øome V≈øhe in a Schoole to teach children to wright. I pro≈øe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe to be of the Vni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ , that's the World; and a Di≈øcipline that the Accademy was never acquainted with all.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: As how ma≈øter Kilvert? I ever preferd the one Art of getting and keeping, above all the ≈øeaven liberall Sciences, for though prodigality be ≈øooner ‚Ä¢ ave at ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ en par≈øimony, yet it is no way ≈øo profitable in my opinion: give me that Learning, which lines the bag, and that Rhetoricke that makes a ratling pocket.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: I ≈øir, (and I ≈øpeake in your eares while you have them) no matter by what indirect meanes the purcha≈øe comes, ≈øo wee may compa≈ø≈øe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, that they ≈øay, is eleven poynts in Law: what care I who the Plaintiffe be, ≈øo I the Defendant can maintayne the fu ‚Ä¢ te with his mony: The≈øe are the rules that guide me, and the principles in tho≈øe Arts I profe≈ø≈øe. I am waited upon three or foure houres in a morning before I ri≈øe by divers Gentlemen to ≈øolicite their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; and will not moove a foote unle≈ø≈øe I have three or foure weighty peeces given me for a fee, Iudge and Iu≈øtice like, for I had ever anitching palme, my Clients ever feed mee largly, tho≈øe peeces made me ≈øpeake Lowder in the Iu≈øtices ears, for I knew I ≈øhould not be Iu≈øtice long.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I ≈øhould be glad to be your Scholler, and make no doubt but in ≈ømal time to prove a good proficient: But I pray ma≈øter Kilvert what u≈øe make you of your Logicke?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: I le tell you ma≈øter Alderman: By Logicke I can wrangle with Worth, intangle Truth, make a bad cau≈øe good, or a good cau≈øe bad: nay more, I can proove Chalke to be Chee≈øe.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: As how, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: As thus, that which is white is Chee≈øe, now Chalke is white as Chee≈øe is white: Ergo Chalke is Chee≈øe.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: But was ever any ≈øo mad as to take Chalke for Chee≈øe?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: O yes, I my ≈øelfe before I came to ≈øerue my fir≈øt ma≈øter, have come into an Ale-hou≈øe and cald for Chee≈øe to my break fa≈øt, and having then no mony to pay for't, my Ho≈øte≈ø≈øe hath bin for≈øt to ≈øcore it up, and ≈øo ≈øhe hath tooke Chalke for Chee≈øe.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: You are plea≈øant M. Kilvert, but now to be more ≈øerious.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p:
Then thus, in ≈øteed of a Procurator, I am turn'd Promoter, and pry into the Lawes both Civil and Common, where no Delinquency of any note can ≈øcape me: and whether the per≈øon that is que≈øtioned be a Peccant or no, if I be not pleas'd, he cannot
≈øcape thence unpuni≈øht, and by that meanes I have pickt many a ≈øimple Clients pocket: and in the Arches from being a Servant, I am now become an Arch-Solicitor, and by that meanes have admittance into all the Courts of iu≈øtice, where I have ≈øubordinate intelligencers, which I allow a groat a day throughout the yeare, that skrew them≈øelves into other mens cau≈øes, and affoord me materials ≈øufficient to worke upon: now, when I have ca≈øt in my conceits to picke an hole in another mans Coate, or to find the lea≈øt flaw by which I may overthrow him or his for tunes, then is my Spirits animated, my peticranion is imployed to purpo≈øe, for my braine upon ≈øuch an occa≈øion is in the mo≈øt able agitation: The very name of Kilvert makes men compound with my Client, if they do but heare that I haue a finger in it, or relli≈øh the Cau≈øe.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Tis true, you haue told me the matter, but not the meanes you worke by.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: To that I was comming, (had you not interrupted mee:) Then do I find out ≈øome one Iudge that hath bought his place at a deare rate, and he is ea≈øily corrupted, for as I have heard ≈øome of them ≈øay, (who died with a ie≈øt in his mouth) that if they buy deare, they mu≈øt ≈øell deare: For I alwayes carry an Elixar about me, by which (if not quite fatuate) yet I can effa≈øcinate his ≈øen≈øes.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: As how I pray you Sir?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: As thus, I can whi≈øper ≈øuch a charme in his eare, as ≈øhal make him deare, ≈øave only to my eares: ca≈øt ≈øuch a filme over his eyes, as ≈øhal make him blind, to my benefit: Lay ≈øuch a tye uppon his tongue, as to temper it to fit mine owne turne. The like power it hath over his Smell, Touch, and Ta≈øt; but folly it were in me to take away his feeling, for that is the principall verbe, the primum mobile, the mayne wheele which mooues the re≈øt of the wheeles.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: And how?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: O, that by no meanes; for I mu≈øt worke upon that Subiect, only to foole the other foure Sen≈øes, for if a cau≈øe (be ≈øuch) be not before felt, it will very difficultly after, be eyther heard or under≈øtood, and though opened as it ought to be, yet wil not iudge as it ≈øhould be: and you know ma≈øter Alderman an A≈ø≈øe laden with Gold may have admittance into the ≈øtronge≈øt Arcenal.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Ma≈øter Kilvert, you are very witty, but proceede, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p:
Fir≈øt, you mu≈øt put that into his hand, which may comfort his heart, or lay that under his cu≈øhion, which ≈øhal never trouble his Con≈øcience: you know my mind. Iu≈øtice was wont (when
her ≈øtatue was to be figured) to be cut out of the whole ≈øtone, but in the≈øe dayes it mu≈øt be made up from peeces. The ≈øpectacles they looke through are not made of gla≈ø≈øe, but gold: and that you know is very ≈øoverain for the ≈øight: and they can ≈øee better with golden eyes then throgh the other brittle and more tran≈øparant mettle: did you never heare Bribo declin'd after the fir≈øt Coniugation?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: I eyther read it in a Pamphlet or heard it in a Play) and as I can be≈øt remember my ≈øelfe, it was thus: Bribo, Bribe-a≈øle (ma≈øter Abel) Bribe-bravely, Bribe-and-I, Bribe-and-do, Bribe-and-Dumbe, Bribe-ba-tum, Bribe-ba-tu, Bribans; Bribe-at-your-hou≈øe; yu under≈øtand me ≈øir.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Yes, very well, I was once a Grammer Scholler my ≈øelfe.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Then but ob≈øerve this cour≈øe (I have it by mine owne Knowledge) your cau≈øe how≈øoever corrupt ≈øhall go on as currant and your ≈øelfe appeare to be as innocuous: as a Martin mounted in the ayre, a Ducke dabling in the Water, or an innocent Lambe of three ≈øcore yeares and upwards.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I am much taken with your Di≈øcour≈øe Mc. Kilvert, and I know you to be a mo≈øt politicke Proiector, mony is the matter we ayme at, and profit the thing that we only pur≈øue: We know what may be done. Now me thinkes it at that we fixe upon ≈øome Proiect to be done, and pre≈øently to have it put in practi≈øe: Tho≈øe Patents for Caske and for Tobaco, and for Cards, and Dice, with divers others, have already pa≈øt the Seale, but what new reach haue you now by which to inrich us?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Give me leave a little to recollect my ≈øelfe, hum, hum,‚Äîlet me ≈øee, Mercers, Gold≈ømith, Drapers, Grocers, you are a Vintner, M. Alderman, what thinke you of a Monopoly or Patent for Wines, and for dre≈ø≈øing of meat.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I doe approve of the proiect exceedingly. But fir≈øt tell me one thing Ma≈øter Kilvert, are you a free man of our City?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: No indeed ≈øir, but for ≈øome rea≈øons be≈øt re≈øerved to my ≈øelf, I would I were.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Let me alone to procure that.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: And then let me alone to extract mony out of your Citty mines; and drawit into our owne pur≈øes.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: And that's profitable proiection: but Ma≈øter Kilvert, in ≈øome things I would intreat you to take my vice (this cough doth ≈øo trouble me) my advi≈øe I ≈øhould have ≈øayd. Buy then your Freedome in the City, a ≈ømall quantity of coyne ≈øhall compa≈ø≈øe it, and in it you ≈øhall have my be≈øt favour and ≈øurtherance. Then, you have choyce to be of what Company you mo≈øt fancy: Which I could wi≈øh to be of the Vintners; of of which Society I am none of the meane≈øt members. That done, I wil bring you in to be one of our Livery, and in a ≈øhort time to be made one of the A≈øi≈øtance; onely you mu≈øt be ≈øworne is ≈øecrecy, and not to di≈øclo≈øe any my≈øtery belonging to our Trade, that may be talkt on at the Table.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: To all the≈øe I ≈øhall ≈øub≈øcribe unto freely. But what thinke you of my former motion, concerning the patent for Wine.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Indeed you now come clo≈øe to me, and talke with me in mine owne element.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: I know you Mr. Alderman to be a man every way Abel, ioyne but your pur≈øe with my policy, and if I procure you not a Patent, thinke me to be a meere paltry fellow, and not worth the name of a Proiector: I am nane of tho≈øe fellowes which were borne in a Dul-age, nor do I dwell at Dul-age; I am accounted wi≈øer then ever my father was.

sp.speaker: Abel
sp.p: Then now Ma≈øter Kilvert acquaint me freely with the proiect upon which we may ground the begging of this Patent.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Marry thus we mu≈øt fir≈øt pretend both in the Merchant and Vintner ≈øome gro≈ø≈øe abu≈øes, and the≈øe no meane ones neyther: for the reforming and rectifying of which, we are Petitioners for this Patent. And that the Merchants ≈øhall pay to the King forty ≈øhillings upon every Tun ere hee ≈øhall vent it to the Vintner: in lieu of which, that the Vintner may be no loo≈øer, he ≈øhall rar≈øe the price al≈øo of his Wines, upon all French Wines a peny in the quart, upon all Spani≈øh Wines two pence the quart: it is no matter how the Subiect ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ffer, ≈øo we get and gaine by it: Now to cover this our Craft (I will not ≈øay Con≈øinage) becau≈øe all things of the like nature carry a pretence for the Kings profit: ≈øo we will allow him a competent proportion of forty thou≈øand pound per annum. When the power of the Patent being punctually executed, will yeild double at lea≈øt, if not treble that ≈øumme, and returne it into the Cofers of the undertakers.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Let me hugge thee my Kilvert; But who do you thinke to be the fitte≈øt man to draw this Patent to the purpo≈øe for fear of over ≈øight or mi≈øtake?

sp.speaker: Kilv
sp.p: Who but Mr. Low that lives in Great S. Bartholmews, one mightily ‚Ä¢ ried up for his Chamber Coun≈øell: Let him but have a ≈øound feeling in the fi≈øt, and then fortune for the French, and fico for the Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: My delicate and dainty Kilvert, thou ≈øhalt ever hereafter be in my Bookes: and no ≈øooner ≈øhall this Patent be ≈øign'd and ≈øeal'd, but for thy pains and advice, thou ≈øhalt have ≈øeaven hundred pound in hand, and two hundred peeces per annum during the date of this Patent.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Mo≈øt ≈øweet and well ≈øounding Abel, every way able both in promi≈øe and performance: if I fayle in the pro≈øecuting of this Patent, may I peri≈øh, and ≈øuffer hereafter ≈øome exemplary puni≈øhment.

sp.speaker: Abel
sp.p: But in all this, we never dreampt of a Parliament.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Tu≈øh, feare not that, we mu≈øt have ≈øome great men to have a feeling in the cau≈øe; and by that meanes backe us: but you ≈øee the ≈øtreame roares contrary: but ≈øay one were cald, I am a man Parliament proofe, and no Mounpar≈øons.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: But thinke you the Commons will not mutter and repine at this?

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Let the mon≈øter multitude murmur, what need we to care? beeing po≈ø≈øe≈øt of the Ca≈øh: Foxes and Crowes fare be≈øt, when they be cur≈øt: and ≈øo I hope ≈øhall We: for when We ≈øhall ≈øit in Commi≈ø≈øion, and have our Refferr√©es, Advi≈øers, Sharers, Complotters and Contractors about us, with full power and authority to countenance them, whom need we fear, or be afraid of.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Mr. Kilvert, I honor thee before all the Fea≈øts in our Hall, nay we are free Vintners, and brothers of the Quill, and are for the mo≈øt part true Troians, and know where to find the be≈øt Buts of Wine in the Seller, and wil pierce them for thee, it ≈øhall be pure Wine from the Grape, not mixt & compounded, but reall and brisk: you thinke there is no Brewers but ≈øuch as ‚Ä¢ ew Ale and Beere, I tel you we do brew and cunger in our Sellers, as much as any Brewer of them all, yea and without fire too, but ≈øo much for that. Me thinkes I ≈øee my ≈øelfe in Cheap ≈øide upon an Hor≈øe richly capari≈øon'd, and my two Shrieves to attend me: and me thinkes thee in thy Ca ‚Ä¢ och drawne by foure hor≈øes, and ≈øhall call to thee, and ≈øay friend Kilvert, give me thine hand, &c.

sp.speaker: Kilv.

p.hi: To which I ≈øhall an≈øwer, God ble≈ø≈øe your Honour my good Lord Maior, &c.

sp.p: This and the like di≈øcour≈øe at meeting, and complement at parting, pa≈øt betwixt them. What effect their Project took, is known to all, and with what power (without pitty) they executed the fore of their Patent, what charge & trouble divers of the be≈øt Vintners about the Town were put too both by fines and commitments: The mi≈øery they ≈øuffered by the Medium Wines and the like: But now (God be pray≈øed) the Tyde is turn'd: And ≈øince that Edict concerning the price of wines was publi≈øhed in print, bearing date, the twenty ≈øixt day of May la≈øt pa≈øt: wherein the afore≈øayd Alderman Abel, and Richard Kilvert were by name brought within the compa≈ø≈øe of exemplary puni≈øhment, for which act of theirs, as they made their poore brother Vintners pur≈øes and hearts ake, ≈øo now I feare this newes will make their heads ake, if not their neckes crack.

Since which time they had an other accidentall interview, at which ≈øome language, but differing in phra≈øe from the former, pa≈øt betwixt them to this purpo≈øe. Now imagine they are met, and their fir≈øt ≈øalutation was by M. Abel.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Kilvert, Thou art a Knave. I ≈øay ≈øirrah thou art a cunning Knave.

sp.speaker: Klv.
sp.p: Setting your Wor≈øhipa≈øide, you are but a plain Pattentee, and all ≈øuch are cald by a Word that begins with the fir≈øt letter of my name.
Mris.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Sirrah ra≈øcal, I ≈øay ≈øo as my husbands ≈øays you are a Knave, and a whore-ma≈øter Knave, and a very ≈ølye crafty Knaue.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: And I tell you Mi≈øtris Abel, your husband hath made mee a brother of his Company; and you Mr. Abel, promi≈øe≈øt when you met in Cheape ≈øide, to take me by the hand.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Of all men living I am bound to cur≈øe thee.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: I confe≈ø≈øe you to be A-bel, but you cannot cur≈øe me in the true kinde, without a Book and a candle.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I hope to ≈øee thee hang'd.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Indeed a Bell cannot bee rung in tune till it be ≈øo. Mris.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Sirra do you know to whom you ≈øpeak.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: You are Parliament proofe with a pox.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: But who the pox would have thought of a Parliament ≈øo ≈øoone?

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: I would I had kept my Tavern ≈øtill in old Fi≈øh-≈øtreet, for then I was counted an hone≈øt man.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Yea, to have tooke a way the ≈øigne of the Ship, and to have had a Bel hang'd in the roome of it.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Thou ha≈øt bin mine undoing.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: And you mine: for as our faults are alike, ≈øo I am afraid our fates will be equall.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: All this was by thy proiects and policy.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: True M. Alderman, but countenanc'd by your pur≈øe & authority.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: Kilvert, thou ha≈øt bin cald kill-Vertue, kill-B ‚Ä¢ nnet, kill-Bi≈øhop, and kil-Fart, and now kill Abell, and I hope thou wilt Kil-thy ≈øelfe.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Take heed to your ≈øelfe, that you do not goe to the Divell quicke.

sp.speaker: Abel.
sp.p: If I do? it is of thy driving. I tell thee Kilvert thou art wor≈øe then Caine.

sp.speaker: Kilv.
sp.p: Indeed, we read that in-old time Caine Kild Abel, but now Abell Kils Caine; and I am afraid th√©re is a young Gregory born to make an end of us both.

By this a great Company of people were gathered about them, which made them part for the pre≈øent: their next meeting is to bee expected either at the Barre where they are to be arraigned, or the place appointed for their puni≈øhment.
The manner and forme how Projectors and Patentees have rode a Tylting in a Parliament time.
